title: How Freddie Ljungberg is enhancing his chances of succeeding Unai Emery
text:
Freddie Ljungberg was promoted to Arsenal’s senior coaching staff in the summer (Picture: Getty)

Freddie Ljungberg is taking steps to make himself indispensable at Arsenal having been promoted to the senior coaching set-up during the summer.

The 42-year-old club legend returned to coach the club’s young players last summer following a brief stint in Germany with Wolfsburg as assistant to former Arsenal academy manager Andries Jonker.

Having played a key role in the development of Bukayo Saka and Joe Willock, Ljungberg effectively swapped jobs with Steve Bould during the close season and, according to The Athletic, he is becoming an increasingly prominent figure behind the scenes.

Ljungberg is said to harbour the ambition to be a No.1 in the near future and wants to station himself as a credible potential successor to Unai Emery, who is now almost halfway through his current three-year contract.

Communication is said to be an area Emery continues to struggle with, highlighted by Saka’s revelation last month that he often struggles to understand his manager’s tactical instructions.

Freddie Ljungberg is learning Spanish in a bid to improve his relationship with Unai Emery (Picture: Getty)

In an attempt to bridge the gap, Ljungberg is reportedly learning Spanish in a bid to ingratiate himself with Emery and Arsenal’s Latin contingent, as well as relay the former Sevilla coach’s advice to the younger members of the first team dressing room.

Before matches, Ljungberg will often take the likes of Saka, Willcok and Reiss Nelson aside and talk them through specific instructions on an iPad, while back at the training centre he will put himself forward to lead additional shooting and dribbling drills.

Cohen Bramall, meanwhile, who was signed by Arsene Wenger but discarded by Emery without having made a first team appearance under the Frenchman’s successor, believes Ljungberg is among the most skilled coaches he has worked with to date.

Freddie Ljungberg has played a key role in the development of Bukayo Saka (Picture: Getty)

‘I’ve worked with Arsene Wenger, I’ve worked with Unai Emery’, the full-back told The Athletic. ‘I’ve worked with big coaches and, for me, Arsene and Freddie are the best ones that I’ve had.

‘He worked with me a lot on my body shape, my first touch. Going forward, he wanted me to shoot more. He would take the time to show me techniques: how to shoot properly using the outside of your foot, for example. With crosses, he showed me you don’t always have to whip it. How to pick someone out. It was always constructive criticism.

‘Your pass had to be precise. You know how Arsenal play, but with Freddie everything had to be perfect. You know: finding the pocket on the half-turn, and playing high, rotating at the right time. When the players got that, it worked perfectly. In my opinion we couldn’t be stopped when we got the plan right.’
